headline: More Chinese Wander Abroad for New Year Holiday

headline: Ellen Pao Loses Silicon Valley Bias Case Against Kleiner Perkins
abstract: A jury rejected allegations of gender discrimination against the venture capital firm, after a hitch caused the judge to order further deliberations.

abstract: The Academy of Nutrition and Dietetics is working to terminate a deal that had allowed Kraft to affix the group’s Kids Eat Right label to its cheese slices.

abstract: Critics call the detention of five people from the publication, over an article about a proposal to allow strict Islamic law, an assault on press freedom.

headline: Colleges Use Anti-Apartheid Strategies to Battle Fossil Fuels
abstract: Can divestment work as a battering ram against the fossil fuel industry the way it did against apartheid in the 1980s?

headline: Shares of Aena and Elis Climb in Strong Demand for European I.P.O.s
abstract: The pace for initial public offerings this year is off to its best start since the financial crisis, with more than a dozen companies making their debuts in the recent weeks.

headline: Do Activist Investors Target Female C.E.O.s?
abstract: Only 23 women lead companies in the Standard & Poor’s 500-stock index. Yet at least a quarter of them have fallen into the cross hairs of activist investors.

headline: Cloud Software Start-Up AppDirect Raises $50 Million
abstract: The company, which specializes in letting clients sell and manage online software systems, plans to expand its staff worldwide.

headline: Data Security Gaps in an Industry Student Privacy Pledge
abstract: Companies that signed on to an industry student privacy pledge have different interpretations of their obligation to maintain security measures for students’ personal details.

headline: European Data Center Providers Agree on All-Share Merger
abstract: Telecity Group and Interxion Holding said the combined company, with a market capitalization of more than $4 billion, would be better able to meet customers’ global data storage and cloud computing needs.

headline: Kyle Bass Wields New Weapon in Challenging Drug Makers
abstract: It’s not clear, though, how Mr. Bass’s hedge fund, Hayman Capital, has an advantage over experienced generic firms, Robert Cyran of Reuters Breakingviews writes.

headline: Morning Agenda: U.S. Presses Banks for Guilty Pleas
abstract: The Justice Department is pushing banks to plead guilty to settle a currency inquiry. | A disproportionate number of companies led by women are the targets of activist investors. | Puerto Rico’s debt plan is in jeopardy. | Profit at UBS rises.

headline: Samsung Tweaks Television Policy Over Privacy Concerns
abstract: After an outcry over privacy concerns, Samsung has clarified that some of its televisions listen in on the conversations of viewers only if the users permit the devices to do so.

headline: Apple Building Solar Farm to Power California Operations
abstract: The company is aggressively adding to its renewable energy sources, a point of pride for its chief executive, Timothy D. Cook.

headline: Chico’s Clothing Stores Near Sale to Sycamore Partners
abstract: If completed, the deal, estimated to be more than $3 billion, would be the largest buyout of the year.

headline: Chinese Regulator Defends Fine Against Qualcomm
abstract: The National Development and Reform Commission said the $975 million punishment was not designed to ‘‘protect any industry, but more importantly to restore market competitiveness.’’

headline: Daily Report: Qualcomm Fined $975 Million by China
abstract: In addition to the fine, which was a record for China, Qualcomm, the chip maker, agreed to sharply reduce the royalties it charges Chinese smartphone makers.

headline: For Many Veterans, ‘American Sniper,’ Right or Wrong, Starts an Important Conversation
abstract: Douglas W. Jackson, a former Marine and Iraq veteran, writes that what the movie “American Sniper” gets right — or wrong –depends on who’s watching. But he thinks the film could play an important role in reminding both veterans and civilians of how unresolved the war’s recent history is.

headline: China Convicts Man of 1996 Crime for Which Another Was Executed
abstract: The ruling by the Intermediate People’s Court of Hohhot came less than two months after Inner Mongolia’s highest court had posthumously exonerated another man of rape and murder.

headline: Daily Report: Rivalry Brewing Between Uber and Google
abstract: Google is a major investor in Uber, but as often happens in Silicon Valley, each company is working on products that could wind up directly competing.

headline: Uber Pledges to Improve Data Privacy Practices
abstract: The ride-hailing start-up responds to criticism from privacy hawks.

headline: President of China Minsheng Bank Steps Down
abstract: The China Minsheng Banking Corporation gave no explanation for the resignation of Mao Xiaofeng and no indication whether he had been questioned or was assisting investigators.

headline: More Chinese Wander Abroad for New Year Holiday
abstract: More than five million Chinese were estimated to have traveled abroad over the Lunar New Year holiday that ended on Wednesday, a 10 percent increase over the year before and the first time Chinese tourists bound for foreign lands outnumbered those vacationing domestically.

headline: Greek Debt Proposals Offer Room for Discussion
abstract: The Greek prime minister will have to make concessions if he wants his country and his banks to be financed past the official end of the current bailout, Pierre Briançon of Reuters Breakingviews writes.

headline: A Year of Columns, a Memorable Trove of Characters
abstract: A columnist meets many characters in the course of a year’s work. Here are a few featured in Common Sense who stood out.

headline: A Stress Test for Mario Draghi and the European Central Bank
abstract: In doing “whatever it takes” to save the eurozone, the head of the European Central Bank now risks dividing it.

headline: French Leader Urges End to Sanctions Against Russia Over Ukraine
abstract: Backing Vladimir V. Putin into a corner will not work, President François Hollande of France said, reflecting sanctions fatigue among European officials.

headline: Tensions Mount as Israel Freezes Revenue Meant for Palestinians
abstract: It is the first of an expected series of punitive measures in response to a push by the Palestinians to prosecute Israeli officials for war crimes during the battle with militants in the Gaza Strip last summer.

headline: December Auto Sales, and Job Data for U.S. and Europe
abstract: On Monday, automakers reported strong December and annual sales, and on Friday, the Labor Department will report on job creation and unemployment.

headline: Selfies on a Stick, and the Social-Content Challenge for the Media
abstract: The tendency to listen to the holy music of the self is reflected not only in the selfie stick, but also in apps like Snapchat and Instagram, which pose a profound challenge for media companies.

headline: From a Private School in Cairo to ISIS Killing Fields in Syria (With Video)
abstract: The West is not alone in struggling to understand why young men like Islam Yaken, raised in homes that would never condone violence, are joining the Islamic State.

headline: New Zealand Glaciers Ebb and Tour Guides Play Catch-Up
abstract: With winter weather more unpredictable in many parts of the world, companies offering tours through ice and snow find an uneven effect on business.
